explanation: BSP_DEBUG: Provide the macro or function declaration (prototype/definition) so the parameter types are known (in particular the type of the format string parameter). MISRA 'pointer to const when possible' is concerned with passing string literals — if BSP_DEBUG's prototype takes a char * (non-const) this would be relevant; if it takes const char * then no violation. OS_API_Init: Its prototype (return type and parameter list) is needed to confirm there are no pointer parameters or pointer-return types involved in the call that would trigger the const-pointer rule. OS_ApplicationExit: Prototype is needed to check whether the Status argument or any other parameter involves pointers (and their const-qualification). int32: The typedef/definition of int32 is needed to check whether it is an alias to a pointer type or otherwise affects type comparisons relevant to MISRA analysis. OS_SUCCESS: The definition (macro/enum/constant) is needed to confirm its type and to ensure no hidden pointer usage or macros that expand to pointer expressions. Together these symbols let the analyzer determine whether any pointers in the target function (notably the format string passed to BSP_DEBUG) are being passed to non-const pointer parameters, which is the crux of the MISRA rule under review.
